vaccines.title: BCG Vaccine
why_important: Protects against childhood tuberculosis, including TB meningitis and disseminated disease
what_to_expect: 0.05 ml injection into right upper arm within the first week (ideally within 24 hours)
May cause a small red bump at the injection site
tips: Always bring the child's vaccine card to the clinic
No fasting required; breastfeeding can continue immediately

vaccines.title: Oral Polio Vaccine (Polio‑0)
why_important: Provides early protection against poliovirus to prevent paralysis
what_to_expect: Two drops orally—no injection needed
Very rare risk of vaccine‑associated paralytic polio in immunodeficient infants
tips: Breastfeeding before and after the dose is fine
Re-administer once if infant vomits immediately after; do not delay vaccination

vaccines.title: Pentavalent‑1 (DTP‑HepB‑Hib)
why_important: Protects against diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, and Hib meningitis
what_to_expect: 0.5 ml intramuscular injection in the left thigh
Possible mild fever or swelling; rare high fever
tips: Do not fast the child
Use separate injection sites if other vaccines are given
Repeat second and third doses at 10w and 14w

vaccines.title: Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV‑1)
why_important: Boosts immunity to polio types 1 and 3 during early infancy
what_to_expect: Two oral drops—no injection
Generally no side effects
tips: Can be administered even if child has mild illness
Give alongside other vaccines during the same visit

vaccines.title: Pneumococcal Vaccine (PCV‑10 or PCV‑13)
why_important: Protects against pneumonia and meningitis caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae
what_to_expect: 0.5 ml intramuscular injection in the right thigh
Mild fever or fussiness for 1–2 days
tips: Complete the series at 6w, 10w and 14w
Offer oral rehydration if mild fever occurs

vaccines.title: Rotavirus Vaccine (Rota‑1)
why_important: Reduces risk of severe diarrhoeal disease, which accounts for ~40 % of childhood deaths in Uganda
what_to_expect: Liquid drops given orally
Possible mild diarrhea, vomiting, or fussiness
tips: Administer while child is calm or breastfeeding
Ensure ≥4 weeks before Rota‑2 dose

vaccines.title: Pentavalent‑2 (DTP‑HepB‑Hib)
why_important: Strengthens immunity against diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, and Hib
what_to_expect: 0.5 ml intramuscular injection; similar mild reactions as Dose 1
tips: Ensure exactly 10 weeks since Dose 1
Record as second dose on vaccine card

vaccines.title: Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV‑2)
why_important: Boosts immunity against poliovirus types 1 and 3
what_to_expect: Two oral drops; no injection
Very rare risk of vaccine‑associated paralysis
tips: Administer even if the child is mildly unwell
Given at the same visit as Pentavalent‑2

vaccines.title: Pneumococcal Vaccine (PCV‑2)
why_important: Reinforces protection against pneumococcal pneumonia and meningitis
what_to_expect: 0.5 ml intramuscular injection; mild local reaction possible
tips: Complete at 6w, 10w, 14w series
Provide comfort and fluids after vaccination

vaccines.title: Rotavirus Vaccine (Rota‑2)
why_important: Completes protection against severe diarrhoeal disease
what_to_expect: Oral drops; possible mild gastrointestinal upset
tips: Administer at least 4 weeks after Rota‑1, not earlier
Ensure child is calm during administration

vaccines.title: Pentavalent‑3 (DTP‑HepB‑Hib)
why_important: Final dose ensures full immunity against five key childhood diseases
what_to_expect: 0.5 ml intramuscular injection; possible mild fever or irritability
tips: Offer paracetamol if fever is high (per local policy)
Ensure immunization card is updated

vaccines.title: Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV)
why_important: Boosts immunity against all three poliovirus types and prevents VAPP
what_to_expect: 0.5 ml intramuscular injection into the thigh; mild soreness possible
tips: Administer at same visit as Pentavalent‑3 using a different limb
Breastfeed before or after dose to soothe baby

vaccines.title: Pneumococcal Vaccine (PCV‑3)
why_important: Completes pneumococcal immunization series in infancy
what_to_expect: 0.5 ml IM injection; minor fever or pain possible
tips: Hydrate the child and encourage gentle feeding
Mark ‘PCV‑3’ on health card

vaccines.title: Measles–Rubella (MR‑1)
why_important: Protects against measles (which can cause blindness/death) and rubella (which causes congenital defects)
what_to_expect: 0.5 ml subcutaneous injection; mild fever or rash possible
tips: Some children may develop a mild rash ~1 week later—normal
Administered alongside Yellow Fever vaccine on the same visit
No fasting needed

vaccines.title: Yellow Fever Vaccine
why_important: Prevents yellow fever, a severe mosquito‑borne disease; one dose gives lifelong protection
what_to_expect: 0.5 ml subcutaneous injection in the right arm
May cause fever, headache or muscle ache after 5–10 days
tips: Keep the vaccination certificate for travel purposes
Contraindicated under 9 months or in severe egg allergy
Free in public clinics since Uganda added it to the routine schedule in 2022

vaccines.title: Measles–Rubella #2 (MR‑2)
why_important: Booster for long-term immunity and catch-up for those who didn’t respond to MR‑1
what_to_expect: 0.5 ml subcutaneous injection; mild fever or rash possible
tips: Given during routine preschool immunization visit
No fasting needed; update vaccine card
